text: Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored. Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful) Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
